title: The Entombment of Christ

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of pen and brown ink, with touches of graphite and a later (?) addition of gray wash to head of christ, on buff laid paper, squared in red chalk, laid down on cream laid paper, laid down on tan wove paper.

description: This monumental composition served as a modello, or presentation drawing, for Barroci's altarpiece in Santa Croce in Senigallia. The sophisticated geometry of Barroci's complex pictorial construction is revealed by his squaring of the work; the unusually energetic and brittle line may indicate his intention to have a print made to publicize this important commission in an out-of-the-way church.
medium_display: Pen and brown ink, with touches of graphite and a later (?) addition of gray wash to head of Christ, on buff laid paper, squared in red chalk, laid down on cream laid paper, laid down on tan wove paper

Adolfo Venturi, Storia dell'Arte Italiana, vol. 9/7 (Milan, 1934).

Lieneke C. J. Frerichs, "Twee grote werktekeningen van Federico Barocci, verworven voor het Rijksmuseum," Bulletin Van Het Rijksmuseum (1978), pp. 3-10.

Brunella Teodori, "Aspetti del baroccismo perugino: Benedetto Bandiera, Felice e Vincenzo Pellegrini,"  Arte e Musica in Umbria tra Cinquecento e Seicento. Atti del XII Convegno di Studi Umbri. Gubbio - Gualdo Tadino, 30 November-2 December 1979 (Gubbio, 1981), pp. 275-99.

Old Master Drawings from Chatsworth, Christie, Manson and Woods, London 1984.

Diane De Grazia, "Refinement and Progression of Barocci's Entombment: The Chicago Modello," The Art Institute of Chicaogo Museum Studies 12 (1985), pp. 31-42.

Marco Tanzi, "Qualche aggiunta al Malosso e alla sua cerchia," Prospettiva (1985), pp. 82-85.

Edmund P. Pillsbury, 'Barocci at Bologna and Florence,' Master Drawings, 14, no. 1, (1986), pp. 56-64.

Anna Fucili Bartolucci, "La Scuola Baroccesca, Claudio Ridolfi e i suoi epigoni," Arte e Cultura nella Provincia di Pesaro e Urbino dalle origini a oggi, ed. by Franco Battistelli (Venice, 1986).

George R. Goldner, Lee Hendrix and Gloria Williams, European Drawings 1: Catalogue of the Collections, The J. Paul Getty Museum (Malibu, California, 1988).

Suzanne Folds McCullagh and Laura M. Giles, Italian Drawings before 1600 in The Art Institute of Chicago:  A Catalogue of the Collection (Chicago, 1997), pp. 17-18, no. 16 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Cleveland Museum of Art, "The Graphic Art of Federico Barocci," exh. cat. by Edmund P. Pillsbury and Louise S. Richards; Yale University Art Gallery, New Haven, 1978, pp. 63-64, cat. 40, ill. (as Barocci).

Amsterdam, Rijksmuseum, Rijksprentenkabinet, "Italiaanse Tekeningen Il de 15de en 16de Eeuw," exh. cat. by L. C. J. Frerichs, 1981.

The Art Institute of Chicago, "Great Drawings from The Art Institute of Chicago: The Harold Joachim Years 1958-1983," July 24-September 30, 1985, pp. 30-31, cat. 4 (ill.), cat. by Martha Tedeschi; traveled to the St. Louis Art Museum, March 10-May 16, 1986.

The Art Institute of Chicago, "Drawings Rediscovered: Italian Drawings before 1600 in the Art Institute of Chicago."  April 10-July 22, 1997.
provenance_text: Jonathan Richardson, Jr. (1665-1745), London [Lugt 2170]. Sir Charles W. A. Oakeley (1825-1915), Tunbridge Wells, Kent, [inscription]; sold, Sotheby's, London, February 13, 1896, Oakeley Sale, lot 32, to Walker.  W. Maxwell Bolton, Larchfield, Cheshire; sold, Sotheby's, London, July 8, 1964, lot 23, to Yvonne French.  Mr. and Mrs. Hans M. Calmann, (1899-1982) London.  Sold by John and Paul Herring and Company, Inc., New York, to the Art Institute, 1983.
